description: This topic is MUCH longer than others. It also doesn't seem geared toward students in any way, and in fact seems written for romantic partners more than anything. Should this be addressed?
There is no feedback written for the 2nd assessment question.
The assessment section of this topic is incomplete. The first question is blank, and both questions have too-short rejoinders.
Again, there are italics in this paragraph that seem important. I am not removing them, but I believe style says there should be no italics for emphasis.
Anne, please see CE comment about feedback not being written for assessment item 1 and determine whether it is intentional or needs feedback.
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment about assessment question for item 2.
Examples of these formal and informal sources?
The sentence "Following these suggestions..." should be on a separate line, correct?
Anne, could you please read Jeremy's comment and confirm if another topic should be bold?
"Your" should be capitalized in topic title.
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment re: missing feedback.
This topic seems short to me... is there supposed to be more text here?
Anne, please see Jeremy's suggestion to reword for clarity.
This topic seems incomplete. Should there be text added to each item here?
Global note: Should the word "not" in an assessment question be italics for emphasis (where needed)?
Explain to whom? Should this be explained further?
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment re: italics emphasizing words in the assessment and address if needed.
The text above the assessment questions reads "Learning with a Difference" which is different than the lesson title.
I don't understand what this means. Can this be clarified?
I don't think "multiple choice" should hyphenated in the title of this topic. But I can't change this.
Should these first sentences be bold, as in other sections?

I've noticed again that the quotation marks in the assessment questions are straight quotes, while those in the main topic are curly/smart quotes. I think a global decision needs to be made about this.

Should "Learn It!" be removed from the title of this topic... the other topics don't contain this.

Also,  the term "Procrastination" is used in the assessment header line,  but "Procrastinating" is used here. Please check this to make consistent.
The rejoinder/rationale for question 2 of the assessments is only "Use  privacy features." Is that thorough enough?
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment below about dividing into multiple paragraphs.
Please check the Assessment question 1... are you sure images should NOT be used in a presentation, as the question indicates? This is not mentioned in the lesson.
The "former slaves" example strikes me as odd... are you saying that these people were very successful after enrolling in college? If so, I think that needs to be explained.
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment about the bold opening sentence.
I removed italics in this topic, including for all mentions of "not-to-do", but not for the "not" in the first sentence, which makes sense to me. Confirm.

In the first assessment question, there should be periods at the end of the 1st row of items (the "tips"). Also, "Test Questions" in the 2nd row ("examples") should be in italics or quotation marks.

Lastly, the second assessment question is a true/false question, and it is formatted differently than in previous topics. Should it be reformatted to match?

Anne, this paragraph is formatted in a way so that the text only up through "...write such breaks into your daily or weekly plan." is visible. Could you please confirm how this para should be formatted? For instance, are there other heads that need to be bold and in a separate item?
Anne, per Jeremy's comment, could you please confirm if feedback should exist for the second question and provide if so?
Assessment question 2 covers material not covered in this topic. Is info missing?
Is it okay for this topic sentence to be bolded this way?
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment about the entire point being bold.
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment about the hyphen in the title. I also cannot edit the title.
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment re: the assessment question.

Anne, please see Jeremy's comments re: use of italics and revise if needed.

Also, please see his comment re: bullets instead of numbered list.
There are no rationales/feedback for answers to the assessment questions for this topic.

There are two sets of assessment questions: "Focusing on Process for Conflict Resolution" and "Conflict Resolution by Focusing on Process". Please confirm you want the first to be attached to this topic.
There were paragraph breaks inside this section. I've deleted them, but please check that this is now correclty formatted.
Anne, I am assuming this narrative is complete and that the principles referenced are included in a different CLA. Could you please confirm?
Seems odd that this is all in bold. Could more be added here?

Should all italics in this topic be removed? They seem to be important in some instances, but I know the stated style is to avoid italics. I have made some changes to delete italics, but left some, as in this paragraph.
Anne, please see Jeremy's note about globally making "not" itals in an assessment.
Anne, could you please confirm what the second bullet should state? The text currently has the same instructions as the first bullet (see Jeremy's comment).
There is no question written for Assessment question 2. Please add.
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment about number of assessment items for this topic.
I moved this sentence to a new paragraph... seems to be a conclusion. Confirm.
I've just noticed that "True" and "False" are capitalized in the assessments for this topic, but I believe in other topics they are not capitalized. I can't change this, and it should be consistent.
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment about the reference to "here"-- what is it referring to? Should content be added?

Global Note: In the preview, the title of these topic (in this case "Practicing Constructive Communication") appears in the Try It! section (right panel), not the Learn It! section (left panel). Is that correct? In other cases the titles does not appear at all in the preview.
Should there be more text here? Is this topic complete?
There is no assessment question #1. Please add.
Anne, could you please see Jeremy's comment about information missing and confirm?
Should the titles of this  topic should be in title case if it will appear on screen: Conflict Resolution with "I" Messages

I'm just noticing here that when I add quotation marks, they appear as straight quotes, not curly quotes. Curly quotes are used in other places in College Success I believe. Is there a way to enable this? I've cheated here by cutting-and-pasting curly quotes from elsewhere in this document, but I don't think this is a good fix.

Also, check assessment question 2, which has quotes as well.
Is this worded correctly: "Here you will learn..."  Where is "here"? There is only one other paragraph in this topic.
Anne, please see Jeremy's comments about the feedback and about amount of content. Is any additional content needed?
There were/are paragraph breaks within this single section. Please confirm that they've been deleted and that this bullet point is formatted correctly.
NOTE: I changed the assessment header from "Tips for Managing your Study Time" to "Managing Your Study Time"
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment below. I agree it's unclear-- maybe it should say "Determine" instead of "Explain". Or if we keep explain, it makes sense to specify to whom.
There's a lot of overlap here with another topic I copyedited... "Set up a Study Group" I believe.
Should this blank image be deleted?
Should these items be in a bulleted list, as in the other topics?
Please confirm change. I think there shoudl be a "Create a table with four columns" instruction here. Maybe that is missing?
Again, I'm leaving some italics here, as it seems to make sense.
There is only one assessment question for this topic (normally there are two).
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment below about missing assessment.
Should there be a bolded topic sentence for any other items?... there is only one now.
Anne, please see Jeremy's comments below.
This paragraph is quite long. I suggest chopping it up.
Should this topic be titled "Managing Student Loans" to be consistent with other topics?
Haha. This guy has crazy eyes.
This topic sentence in bold is incorrect... it repeats the previous bullet point. Reword.
"gauge your depth for learning the material" isn't clear to me... can that be reworded for clarity?
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment about punctuation. I don't seem to have editing rights in the assessments.
This is written as if to indicate that there is a list of these "basic principles" to follow, but nothing does. Is this topic incomplete?
This should be "Learn it!", right?
No feedback written for assessment question 1.
This paragraph mentions "logical fallacies" as well as cognitive biases, suggesting this will come after the "logical fallacies" CLA. Is that correct?
Is this sentence supposed to be in bold?
Anne, please see Jeremy's comment and revise if you think examples of sources should be provided.
This is a repeat of the first bullet item... there is no listing for the second column of this list.
